Subsection.Text: Subject to this section, this Part applies to a ship that is a steamship of more than five tons gross tonnage, built or converted for the purpose of towing, but does not apply to such a ship that, when used for towing, is used only for salvaging logs.
Sections 115 to 132, 138 to 141 and 143 do not apply to an existing ship until

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a ship for which on April 1, 1972 there is a certificate in force, the first day on which the certificate is due for renewal; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a ship for which on April 1, 1972 there is no certificate in force, April 1, 1972.

Subsection.Text: Where an existing ship requires modification to comply with any of sections 115 to 132, 138 to 141 or 143, the modification work shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: begin on or before the date on which those sections come into force with respect to the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if not completed at the time those sections come into force with respect to the ship, be resumed at intervals, not exceeding one year, that are satisfactory to a steamship inspector; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be completed by April 1, 1976.

Subsection.Text: Where the modification work referred to in subsection (3) does not begin on or before the date required by that subsection or where at any time after that date the proportion of that work completed is less than a proportion that is satisfactory to a steamship inspector, the ship shall not be used for towing until the proportion of that work completed is a proportion that is satisfactory to a steamship inspector.

Section.Text: Where an existing ship is modified and the modification work begins on or after October 1, 1971 and if, in the opinion of the Board, it is reasonable and practicable for the ship to comply with all of this Part, the Board may declare the ship to be a new ship.

Upon consideration of the class of voyage and type of operation on which an existing ship is engaged, the Board may, if it is satisfied that the standard of safety required by this Part is not lowered thereby, accept any constructional arrangement on that ship as complying with these Regulations.

Every new ship with openings in the main deck aft of the engine room that are capable of causing down flooding shall be designed and constructed so that, in any operating condition, positive buoyancy and stability are retained and no part of the main deck is submerged when any one watertight compartment aft of the engine room is flooded.
Subject to section 107, no ship shall be used for towing until its stability characteristics have been approved by the Board.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 107, the owner of a ship shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: arrange for an inclining experiment to be conducted on the ship in the presence of and to the satisfaction of a steamship inspector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Board in respect of the ship the following basic stability data:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: hydrostatic curves,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: cross curves of stability,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a capacity plan showing the capacities of all tanks and cargo spaces and the related vertical and longitudinal centres of gravity,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: tank sounding tables,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: draught mark locations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the results of the inclining experiment referred to in paragraph (a); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Board, in respect of the ship, the developed stability data computed for each of the following conditions:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: light ship condition,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: departure from port with 100 per cent fuel, fresh water and stores,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: worst intact stability condition, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: arrival in port with 10 per cent fuel, fresh water and stores.

Subsection.Text: The results of the experiment referred to in paragraph (1)(a) shall be taken into account when computing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the developed stability data referred to in paragraph (c) of that subsection; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the stability data referred to in subsection 108(1) in the case of a new ship.

Subsection.Text: The free surface effect of liquid in tanks shall be taken into account when computing a righting lever curve or a metacentric height for the purposes of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the developed stability data referred to in paragraph (1)(c); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the flooded conditions referred to in paragraphs 108(1)(b) and (c).

Subsection.Text: Every righting lever curve shall show the angle at which the edge of the main deck submerges.
Subject to the approval of the Board,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the immersed volume of any structure provided with weathertight closing appliances, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the immersed volume of any structure up to the level of the bottom of the lowest exterior opening not closed by a weathertight closing appliance,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: may be taken into account when computing a righting lever curve.

Subsection.Text: The owner of a ship shall provide on the ship, for the use of the master, stability information in respect of the ship in the form of a booklet approved by the Board.

The Board may, on application by the owner of a ship, dispense with the inclining experiment referred to in paragraph (1)(a) in respect of the ship if the stability characteristics of a sister ship have been approved as required by section 105.
Sections 105 and 106 do not apply to an existing ship unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the main propelling machinery of the ship is changed for machinery developing greater brake power;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the main propelling machinery of the ship is changed and the difference in weight between the new and the old installation is, in the opinion of the Board, sufficient to adversely affect the stability of the ship; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the ship is modified to such an extent that, in the opinion of the Board, its stability is adversely affected.

Subsection.Text: Where the Board is of the opinion that modifications made to a ship adversely affect its stability within the meaning of paragraph (1)(c), the owner of that ship shall submit such of the stability data described in section 106 as the Board may request.
In the case of a new ship, the owner shall, subject to subsection (2), submit to the Board in respect of the ship the following stability data:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the forward and aft draughts when the watertight compartment aft of the engine room that would cause the greatest reduction in freeboard is completely flooded;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the metacentric height when the watertight compartment aft of the engine room that would cause the greatest reduction in the metacentric height is completely flooded; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the metacentric height when the watertight compartment aft of the engine room that would cause the greatest reduction in the metacentric height in a partly flooded condition is flooded to that condition.

Subsection.Text: Subsections 106(2) to (5) apply when computing the stability data referred to in subsection (1).
In the case of a new ship, the ship shall be fitted with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a collision bulkhead in an approved location; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a watertight bulkhead at the forward end and at the aft end of the main propelling machinery placed as close together as is practicable.

Subsection.Text: Where the forward bulkhead of the engine room of any ship is fitted in an approved location, it may be approved as the collision bulkhead.

Where, in the opinion of the Board, it is reasonable and practicable, every new ship that is propelled by steam engines shall be fitted with a watertight bulkhead between the boilers and the main engines.

Section.Text: In the case of a new ship, where an access opening is fitted in the watertight boundary bulkhead of a watertight compartment referred to in section 104 or in any bulkhead referred to in section 109, the access opening shall, unless it is a tank manhole, be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: made as small as practicable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: placed as near to the top of the bulkhead as is practicable, except in the case of an access opening between machinery spaces or to a shaft tunnel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: reinforced so that the strength of the bulkhead is not reduced by the opening; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: fitted with a watertight closing appliance that conforms to the requirements of section 111.

Section.Text: The watertight closing appliance required by paragraph 110(d) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be an approved watertight closing appliance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in combination with the reinforcing of the opening, be at least as strong as the unpierced bulkhead;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of being opened and closed watertight from each side of the bulkhead and, in the case of a ship of 24.1 m in length or over, capable of being closed watertight from a position above the main deck; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be provided with a position indicator light in the wheelhouse that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: actuated by the closing appliance,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: lighted when the closing appliance is open,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: serviced by a standby circuit and lamp that are automatically brought into operation when the normal circuit or lamp fails, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: visible by the helmsman at the main steering position.

Section.Text: The collision bulkhead of a ship of 15 tons, gross tonnage, or less may be fitted with a drain cock that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has a straight through bore of not more than 38 mm in diameter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is self-closing;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is attached directly to the collision bulkhead; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: drains directly into the bilge without the addition of any piping.

Section.Text: Every closing appliance fitted in a watertight boundary bulkhead of a watertight compartment referred to in section 104 or in any bulkhead referred to in section 109 shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when the ship is underway except when the appliance is in use, be kept closed and fully secured;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: unless it is a tank manhole closure, be provided with a notice on each side of the appliance stating that the appliance is to be kept closed and fully secured when the ship is underway except when the appliance is in use; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be provided with a notice, adjacent to the position indicator light in the wheelhouse, stating that every closing appliance fitted in a watertight boundary bulkhead of a watertight compartment referred to in section 104 or in any bulkhead referred to in section 109 shall be kept closed and fully secured when the ship is underway except when the appliance is in use.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a new ship of 13.7 m in length or over, every crew access opening that gives direct access to a space below the main deck shall be an interior opening.
Notwithstanding subsection (1), a crew access opening provided for emergency escape or any other crew access opening not used in the usual daily routine of the ship may be an exterior opening.
Subject to subsection (3), every space usually occupied by crew when a ship is under way,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a compartment below the main deck of the ship shall be provided with two crew access openings, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a structure on or above the main deck where the ship is a new ship, shall be provided with two exterior crew access openings,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and to both of such crew access openings there shall be ready access from anywhere inside the compartment or structure.

Subsection.Text: The openings referred to in subsection (1) shall be so located that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a single incident occurring inside or outside the compartment or structure, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a list to either side of the ship

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: will not prevent the use of both openings at the same time.

Subsection.Text: Where the provision of two exterior crew access openings for a structure on or above the main deck of a new ship is impracticable because of the structure’s small size, the structure may, subject to approval, be provided with a single exterior crew access opening.
Every crew access opening that gives access to a space usually occupied by crew when a ship is under way shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a clear opening of not less than 560 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be free of any projections that could catch in clothing or lifejackets; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the opening is a hatch, be provided with a fixed ladder or other means of easy access.

Subsection.Text: No hatch to which this section applies shall be located where heavy towing equipment can fall across the hatch cover.

Heading.TitleText: Closing Appliances for Crew Access Openings

Section.Text: For the purposes of sections 119 and 120,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: type ‘A’ closing appliance means a gasketed closing appliance of approved construction that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is fitted in an opening adequately stiffened to provide strength equivalent to that of the unpierced bulkhead or deck in which it is fitted,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is attached by hinges or some other approved method,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is capable of being,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: in the case of a door, closed securely by clamps all around the perimeter of the door or opening, spaced a mean distance of not more than 762 mm apart, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: in the case of a hatch cover, closed securely by not less than two clamps, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: provides the same weathertight integrity as the unpierced bulkhead or deck in which it is fitted; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: type ‘B’ closing appliance means a close fitting closing appliance of approved construction that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is fitted in an opening adequately stiffened to provide strength equivalent to that of the unpierced bulkhead or deck in which it is fitted,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is attached by hinges or some other approved method, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is capable of being closed securely by not less than two clamps.

Subsection.Text: No sliding closing appliance for a crew access opening shall be set athwartships.
No closing appliance for an opening that gives access to a space usually occupied by crew when a ship is under way shall be fitted with a hasp and staple.
Every closing appliance for a crew access opening that is fitted with a locking device shall be capable of being readily unlocked from inside without the use of a key.
Every closing appliance for a crew access hatch shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: balanced by a spring, except where the weight of the appliance makes this provision unnecessary; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a closing appliance fitted to an opening provided for emergency escape, painted a bright orange colour inside and out and clearly marked to indicate that it is to be opened only during drills and emergencies.

Subsection.Text: Every closing appliance for a crew access opening shall be capable of being secured and unsecured from both inside and outside the space to which it gives access.

Where the space referred to in subsection (5) is usually occupied by crew when the ship is under way, the means for securing and unsecuring the closing appliance shall be a single action mechanism that requires only one hand to operate.
Subject to subsection (4), every exterior crew access opening

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the main deck or in a forecastle deck in the bow section, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a structure, other than a wheelhouse, set on a deck referred to in paragraph (a) and through which flooding could occur into a space below the main deck,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: shall be fitted with a type ‘A’ closing appliance.

Subsection.Text: Every exterior crew access opening in a wheelhouse shall be fitted with a close fitting closing appliance of substantial construction, framing and attachment.
Every hinged exterior door shall be hinged on the forward side and open outwards.

In the case of an existing ship, if a type ‘B’ closing appliance is fitted to every crew access opening that gives direct access to space below the main deck from inside a structure described in subsection (1), any exterior crew access opening in that structure may be fitted with a type ‘B’ closing appliance, but, where major alterations or repairs are being made to the structure, every exterior crew access opening therein shall be fitted with a type ‘A’ closing appliance.
Every interior crew access opening that gives direct access to a space below the main deck from inside a wheelhouse shall be fitted with a type ‘A’ closing appliance.

Subject to subsection (3), every interior crew access opening that gives direct access to a space below the main deck, other than an opening described in subsection (1), shall be fitted with a closing appliance that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in association with the reinforcing of the opening is of equivalent strength to the unpierced structure in which it is set;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is close fitting and supported around the perimeter against external pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if hinged, opens outwards from the space below the main deck;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if it gives access to the engine room, is self-closing and is provided with a fire protective sheathing on the engine room side; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if it gives access from an accommodation space to the engine room, is gastight.

Subsection.Text: An interior crew access opening that gives direct access to a watertight accommodation space below the main deck is not required to be fitted with a closing appliance where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the opening is located inside a structure in which every exterior crew access opening is fitted with a type ‘A’ closing appliance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no part of the main deck is submerged when that accommodation space is completely flooded.

Subsection.Text: Every interior door that gives access to an accommodation space and that is not required by these Regulations to be fitted with a type ‘A’ closing appliance, a type ‘B’ closing appliance or a closing appliance described in subsection (2) shall be fitted with a kick-out panel in the lower half of the door.
Every exterior stowage hatchway shall be made as small as is practicable and fitted with an approved weathertight cover.
Every exterior skylight shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: of weathertight construction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: made as small as is practicable;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fitted with circular glass panels of an approved thickness that shall, where the skylight is located aft of the towing point, be protected on the exterior side by substantial guards; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: fitted with hinged deadlights that may be readily closed when the ship is under way.

Section.Text: Every crew access opening shall be provided with a door-sill or coaming that complies with section 123 and every exterior stowage hatchway and skylight shall be provided with a coaming that complies with section 125.

Subsection.Text: In this section, freeboard plane means the plane that is parallel to the deepest load waterplane of a ship and tangent to the line of sheer taken at the level of the upper surface of the main deck, excluding any raised portions thereof, but including any sheathing.
The door-sill or coaming top of every

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: exterior crew access opening

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in a wheelhouse,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: through which no flooding could occur into a space below the main deck, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: located on any deck, other than the part of a forecastle deck in the bow section or the main deck, and through which flooding could occur into a space below the main deck, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: interior crew access opening that gives direct access from a space above the main deck to a space below the main deck

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: shall be not less than 150 mm above the deck outside the door-sill or coaming.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (4) and (5), the door-sill or coaming top of every exterior crew access opening, other than a wheelhouse door opening, located on the part of a forecastle deck in the bow section or on the main deck and through which flooding could occur into a space below the main deck shall be not less than 610 mm the deck outside the door-sill or coaming.

Where a crew access opening described in subsection (3) is located on a raised portion of the main deck extending aft not more than three-quarters of the length of the ship, the height of its door-sill or coaming may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a door-sill or coaming located in the part of the forward half-length of the ship not in the bow section, be reduced by 460 mm or an amount equal to one-quarter of the vertical distance between the freeboard plane and the upper surface of the deck outside the mid-point of the opening, whichever is the lesser;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the door-sill of a doorway located in the aft half-length of the ship, be reduced by 460 mm or an amount that would reduce the height of the door-sill to a level 610 mm above the freeboard plane, whichever is the lesser; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the coaming of a hatch located in the aft half-length of the ship, be reduced by 305 mm or an amount that would reduce the height of the coaming top to a level 610 mm above the freeboard plane, whichever is the lesser.

Subsection.Text: The door-sill or coaming top of every exterior crew access opening referred to in subsection (3) on a ship that has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: no sleeping accommodation on board,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no accommodation of any kind below the main deck, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a type ‘A’ closing appliance fitted to every crew access opening that gives direct access to a space below the main deck

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: shall be not less than 150 mm above the deck outside the door-sill or coaming.

Section.Text: Notwithstanding section 123, where a door-sill on an existing ship does not comply with that section, a permanently attached coaming of a height prescribed for the door-sill in that section shall be fitted inside the doorway, but where major repairs to the door are required or a new door is required, the door-sill shall be altered to comply with section 123.

Subsection.Text: Every exterior stowage hatchway and skylight on a ship shall be fitted with a coaming the top of which

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is 610 mm above the deck at the coaming, in the case of the coaming of an opening located on the part of a forecastle deck in the bow section or on the main deck forward of the towing point;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is 305 mm above the deck outside the coaming, in the case of the coaming of an opening located on

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any part of a forecastle deck aft of the bow section,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any deck above the main deck, or other than a forecastle deck, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the main deck aft of the towing point that is not opened in the usual daily routine of the ship when it is under way; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is 610 mm above the deck outside the coaming, in the case of the coaming of an opening located on the main deck aft of the towing point that is opened in the usual daily routine of the ship when it is under way.

Subsection.Text: Every interior stowage hatchway on the main deck shall be provided with a coaming the top of which is not less than 150 mm above the deck outside the coaming.
Subject to subsection (2), every ventilation opening on a ship shall be located

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as close to the centre line of the ship as is practicable, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as high above the main deck as is practicable,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: but on no ship shall the lower edge of the opening be less than 915 mm above the main deck.

Subsection.Text: The Board may approve a ventilation opening the lower edge of which is less than 915 mm above the main deck if it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is self-closing when submerged; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does not ventilate the engine room.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 128, every window frame and sidelight frame shall have a strength appropriate to the strength of the bulkhead to which it is fastened and shall be fitted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a window, with toughened glass of an approved thickness, but in no case less than 6 mm thick; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a sidelight, with glass of an approved thickness.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), at least one window or sidelight that opens to give a clear opening of not less than 460 mm shall be provided in every fully enclosed cabin, messroom, galley or other accommodation space on or above the main deck that has only one crew access opening, and an exterior hand bar shall be fixed over each such window or sidelight.

Where during the normal operation of a ship a window or sidelight fitted in the side of a superstructure of the ship might be in contact with another ship, no window or sidelight is required to be provided in that side of the superstructure.

Subject to subsection (5), no window shall be located so that the bottom of the aperture, if the window opens, or the bottom of the glass aperture, if the window does not open, is less than 610 mm above the main deck or forecastle deck, as the case may be.
The bottom of every window located in the bow section, other than a wheelhouse window, shall be not less than 2.75 m vertically above the weather deck at that location.

At least one sliding window that gives a clear opening of not less than 560 mm shall be provided on each side of every wheelhouse, unless the wheelhouse has more than one exterior crew access opening and the provision of such a sliding window is not practicable.
No sidelight shall be located below the main deck.
Every sidelight in a structure set on the main deck or a forecastle deck that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: can be opened, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has a glass aperture of more than 250 mm in diameter

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: shall be so located that the bottom of the aperture, if the sidelight opens, or the bottom of the glass aperture, if the sidelight does not open, is at least 610 mm above the main deck or forecastle deck, as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: Every sidelight in the bow section shall be fitted with an internal hinged deadlight.
Every sidelight not in the bow section shall be fitted with an internal shutter attached to the frame by a keep chain or an internal hinged deadlight.
Every window, other than a wheelhouse window, in a structure set on the main deck shall be fitted with a permanently attached internal shutter or hinged deadlight.
Every wheelhouse window that faces forward or athwartships shall be provided with a shutter that, if it is not permanently attached, shall be kept readily available.
Subsection 127(1) does not apply to an existing ship unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the glass is replaced in a window, in which case it shall be fitted with the glass required by that subsection; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a frame is replaced, in which case it shall be replaced with a frame that complies with that subsection.

Subsection.Text: Subsections 127(4), (5), (7) and (8) do not apply to an existing ship, unless modifications are made to the ship and, in the opinion of the Board, it is reasonable and practicable for the ship to comply with those subsections.
A window in a structure set on the main deck of an existing ship that does not comply with subsection 127(11) shall be fitted with an internal shutter attached to the frame by a keep chain.

A sidelight that is located below the main deck of an existing ship and a sidelight on such a ship that does not comply with subsection 127(9) or (10) shall, where not fitted with a permanently attached deadlight, be fitted with an internal shutter attached to the frame by a keep chain.

Where the steering of a ship can be controlled from more than one position, a safeguard shall be fitted to each steering control operated by a steering lever to prevent inadvertent operation of that lever.
Every electrically operated rudder angle indicator shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: so constructed that, when the power supply to the rudder angle indicator system is cut off, neither amidships nor any other rudder angle is indicated; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fitted with a visual annunciator that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: indicates when the power supply to the rudder angle indicator system is cut off,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: resets automatically when power is supplied to the rudder angle indicator system, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is incorporated in the rudder angle indicator box or mounted separately close to the indicator.

Section.Text: Each steering position that is not in direct voice contact with the towing winch control position at the winch shall be connected to that control position by a two-way communication system.

Subsection.Text: Every ship on which a towline is attached to a winch shall have at each steering position a control by means of which any tension in the towline can be reduced immediately.
Every ship on which the winch can be controlled from more than one position shall be fitted with an arrangement that prevents more than one position from exercising control at any one time.
Every winch control shall be fitted with a safeguard to prevent the inadvertent operation of the control.
Every existing ship on which a towline is attached to a winch that is not fitted with the control referred to in subsection 132(1), shall be fitted with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an effective winch drum brake that can be applied and released by hand without the use of a bar; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a mechanism whereby any clutch that transmits power to the winch drum can be effectively secured in the disengaged position.

Subsection.Text: The arrangements that are required by subsection (1) shall, before being put into operation and at such other times as a steamship inspector may request, be demonstrated under operating conditions to a steamship inspector.

Section.Text: No towing winch shall be fitted with a ratchet device that could prevent the winch from paying out the towline.
Every ship on which the towline is attached to a bollard or to bitts shall have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a mechanical arrangement able to sever or release the towline immediately; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an axe for cutting the towlines clearly marked to indicate its purpose and stowed near to bollard or bitts.

Section.Text: Every ship on which a towline is attached to a hook shall have at each steering position a control by means of which the towline can be released from the hook immediately.
An existing ship that does not comply with sections 133 to 136 shall not be used to pull a floating object.

Subsection.Text: Every ship, the propelling machinery of which develops brake power of 373 kW or over shall, if fitted with towing pins on the counter, have such pins power operated.
The control position for power operated towing pins on a ship shall be forward of the point of tow and the pins shall be clearly visible from the control position.
Every bulwark forming a well on the main deck or a superstructure deck of a ship shall be provided with freeing ports.

Subject to subsection (3), the minimum number of square metres in the total area of the freeing ports on each side of a well on a ship shall be determined by dividing the number of metres in the length of that well by 13.

If the average height of a bulwark forming a well is less than 0.9 m, the total area of the freeing ports in the bulwark may be decreased by 0.004 m2 per metre length of bulwark for each 0.1 m by which the average height of the bulwark is less than 0.9 m.
The freeing ports shall be distributed in a manner that achieves the maximum speed of drainage from the decks.
Bars or shutters shall, if necessary, be fitted in each freeing port so as to restrict the clear openings to not more than 230 mm.

Section.Text: Every working area in a ship and any exterior part of a ship on which a person may stand during the normal operation of the ship shall have a durable non-skid surface.

Subsection.Text: Every structure on the main deck of a ship around which a person must walk during the normal operation of the ship shall have storm rails attached to the exterior of the structure.
Each storm rail shall be attached to a structure

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the ends of the rail by fastenings attached to the inside or ends of the rail; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at intermediate points not more than 1.2 m apart by fastenings attached to the bottom of the rail.

Section.Text: In the case of a new ship, every anchor chain locker shall be so constructed that the chain is self-stowing.

An existing ship 24.4 m in length or over on which the anchor chain is not self-stowing shall have a two-way communication system between the inside of the chain locker and the windlass control position.

ScheduleFormHeading.Label: SCHEDULE I
ScheduleFormHeading.TitleText: Calculation of Maximum Length of Watertight Compartments

Section.Text: For the purposes of this Schedule, except where otherwise specified,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all linear measurements shall be in metres;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all volumes shall be in cubic metres and shall be calculated from measurements taken to moulded lines;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the symbol “L” denotes the length of the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the expression “passenger spaces” shall include galleys, laundries and other similar spaces provided for the service of passengers, in addition to space provided for the use of passengers; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: plans of the subdivision arrangements and calculations as follows shall be submitted:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: outline profile and plans showing the margin lines (corrected as necessary); all watertight transverse and longitudinal bulkheads, decks, inner skins, shaft and other tunnels, trunks and ventilators; recesses and steps in watertight bulkheads; double bottoms, the principal openings in the watertight bulkheads and decks and openings therein closed only by portable plates, the appropriation of spaces below the bulkhead deck; the positions of equivalent plane bulkheads; the lengths of the main transverse compartments and the weathertight arrangements at the forward end; tunnels, recesses and steps shall be shown in plan and elevation and typical sections of the double bottom shall be given, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: subdivision coefficients and particulars on forms BH2 and BH2A, calculations of equivalent plane bulkheads, allowances for local subdivision, flooding calculations and curves and the particulars required to enable the Board to determine whether a detailed calculation of permeability is required under clause 3(b)(i)(B) and paragraph 8(b).

Section.Text: Subject to section 6 of this Schedule, the length of a compartment shall not exceed its permissible length; the permissible length of a compartment having its centre at any point shall be the product of the floodable length at that point and the factor of subdivision of the ship; to enable the permissible length of compartments to be determined, it will be necessary to develop flooding curves that will indicate the floodable length at any point in the ship; flooding curves should be developed by a method of calculation that takes account of the form, draught and other characteristics of the ship; the method described in Division IV of this Schedule should normally be used; if, however, the ship is of such unusual form that this method is not sufficiently accurate, the Board may permit the use of an alternative method of calculation.

Heading.TitleText: All Ships Referred to in Section 8 of Part I Except Ships of Class II and Class III Specified in Division III of this Schedule

Section.Text: The assumptions of permeability, which shall be taken into account in determining the floodable length at any point in ships to which this Division applies, shall be as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: machinery space:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of ships not propelled by internal combustion engines, the assumed average permeability throughout the machinery space shall be determined by the following formula:

FormulaDefinition.Text: = volume of the passenger spaces and crew spaces below the margin line within the limits of the machinery space;
= volume of the between deck spaces below the margin line within the limits of the machinery space which are appropriated to cargo, coal or stores; and
= volume of the machinery space below the margin line,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of ships propelled by internal combustion engines, the average permeability throughout the machinery space shall be taken as five greater than that given by the aforesaid formula, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in any case in which the average permeability throughout the machinery space, as determined by detailed calculation, is less than that given by the aforesaid formula, the calculated value may be substituted; for the purposes of such calculation, the permeability of passenger spaces and crew spaces shall be taken to be 95, that of all spaces appropriated for cargo, coal or stores shall be taken to be 60, and that of double bottom, oil fuel and other tanks forming part of the structure of the ship shall be taken to be 95 or such lesser figure as the Board may approve in the case of that ship; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: portions before and abaft the machinery space:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the assumed average permeability throughout the portions of the ship before and abaft the machinery space shall be determined:

FormulaDefinition.Text: = volume of the passenger spaces and crew spaces which are situated below the margin line before or abaft the machinery space, as the case may be; and
= volume of the portion of the ship below the margin line before or abaft the machinery space, as the case may be, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: if the Board so determines in the case of any ship, after receipt of a plan of the ship showing the watertight subdivisions thereof, by detailed calculation, for the purpose of which the permeability of spaces shall be assumed to be as follows:

Provision.Text: passenger spaces 95
crew spaces 95
spaces appropriated to machinery 80
spaces appropriated to cargo, coal, stores or baggage rooms 60
tanks forming part of the structure of the ship and double bottoms 95,
or such lesser figure as the Board may permit in the case of any ship; and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for the purposes of this section, a space within a passenger space or crew space shall be deemed to be a part thereof unless it is appropriated for other purposes and is enclosed by permanent steel bulkheads.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), in the case of ships the length of which is 131 m or more, the factor of subdivision F shall be determined by the following formula:

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), in the case of ships the length of which is less than 131 m but not less than 79 m having a criterion numeral of not less than

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the factor determined in accordance with subsection (5) and Cs is the criterion numeral determined in accordance with section 5 of this Schedule.

Subsection.Text: In the case of ships the length of which is less than 131 m but not less than 79 m and having a criterion numeral less than S or in the case of ships the length of which is less than 79 m the factor of subdivision shall be unity.
In the case of a ship of any length which is intended to carry a number of passengers exceeding 12 but not exceeding

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: whichever is the lower, the factor of subdivision shall be determined in the manner provided in subsection (3).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this subsection the factors A and B shall be determined by the following formulae:

Section.Text: The criterion numeral for ships to which this Division applies shall be determined by the following formulae:

Provision.Text: When P1 is greater than P

FormulaDefinition.Text: = the volume of the machinery space, with the addition thereto of the volume of any permanent oil fuel bunkers which may be situated above the inner bottom and before or abaft the machinery space;
= the volume of the passenger spaces and crew spaces below the margin line;
= the volume of the ship below the margin line;
= number of passengers which the ship is intended to carry; and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the value of 0.056LN is greater than the sum of P and the whole volume of the passenger spaces above the margin line, the figure to be taken as P1 shall be that sum or 0.037LN whichever is the greater;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: values of Cs less than 23 shall be taken as 23; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: values of Cs greater than 123 shall be taken as 123.

Subsection.Text: Compartments exceeding the permissible length:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a compartment may exceed its permissible length provided that the combined length of each pair of adjacent compartments to which the compartment in question is common does not exceed either the floodable length or twice the permissible length, whichever is the lesser;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if one compartment of either of such pairs of adjacent compartments is situated inside the machinery space, and the other compartment thereof is situated outside the machinery space, the combined length of the two compartments shall be adjusted in accordance with the mean average permeability of the two portions of the ship in which the compartments are situated;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the lengths of two adjacent compartments are governed by different factors of subdivision, the combined length of the two compartments shall be determined proportionately; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where in any portion of a ship bulkheads required by these Regulations to be watertight are carried to a higher deck than in the remainder of the ship, separate margin lines may be used for calculating the floodable length of that portion of the ship, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the two compartments adjacent to the resulting step in the bulkhead deck are each within the permissible length corresponding to their respective margin lines and, in addition, their combined length does not exceed twice the permissible length determined by reference to the lower margin line of such compartments, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the sides of the ship are extended throughout the ship’s length to the deck corresponding to the uppermost margin line and all openings in the shell plating below that deck throughout the length of the ship comply with the requirements of section 19 as if they were openings below the margin line.

Subsection.Text: In ships 131 m in length and upwards, the watertight bulkhead next abaft the collision bulkhead shall be fitted at a distance from the forward perpendicular that is not greater than the permissible length appropriate to a compartment bounded by the forward perpendicular and such bulkhead.
If a bulkhead required by these Regulations to be watertight is stepped, it shall comply with one of the following conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in ships having a factor of subdivision not greater than 0.9, the combined length of the two compartments separated by such bulkhead shall not exceed 90 per cent of the floodable length or twice the permissible length, whichever is the lesser; in ships having a factor of subdivision greater than 0.9, the combined length of the two compartments shall not exceed the permissible length;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: additional subdivision is provided in way of the step to maintain the same measure of safety as that secured by a plane bulkhead; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the compartment over which the step extends does not exceed the permissible length corresponding to a margin line taken 76 mm below the step.

Subsection.Text: If any part of a recess lies outside vertical surfaces on both sides of the ship situated at a distance from the shell plating equal to one fifth of the breadth of the ship and measured at right angles to the centre line at the level of the deepest subdivision load water line, the whole of such recess shall be deemed to be a step in a bulkhead for the purposes of subsection (3).
Where a bulkhead required by these Regulations to be watertight is recessed or stepped, an equivalent plane bulkhead shall be assumed in determining the subdivision.

If the distance between two adjacent bulkheads required by these Regulations to be watertight, or their equivalent plane bulkheads, or the distance between transverse planes passing through the nearest stepped portions of the bulkheads, is less than 0.03L + 3.05 m, or 10.67 m, or 0.1L, whichever is the least, only one of those bulkheads shall be regarded as forming part of the subdivision of the ship; for Class V and Class VIII vessels, this minimum spacing shall be applicable between peak bulkheads.

Where in any ship a main transverse watertight compartment contains local subdivision and the Board is satisfied that, after any assumed side damage extending over a length of 0.03L + 3.05 m, or 10.67 m, or 0.1L, whichever is the least, the whole volume of the main compartment will not be flooded, a proportionate allowance may be made in the permissible length otherwise required for such compartment; in such a case the volume of effective buoyancy assumed on the undamaged side shall not be greater than that assumed on the damaged side.

Heading.Label: DIVISION III
Heading.TitleText: Ships of Class II and Class III to which Section 8 of Part I Applies That Are Permitted by the Board, in Exercise of its Power under Subsection 7(6) of the Life Saving Equipment Regulations to Carry Persons in Excess of the Lifeboat Capacity Provided on Board

Section.Text: Subject to the modifications set forth in this Division, the maximum length of compartments in ships to which this Division applies shall be determined as if they were ships to which Division II applies.

Heading.TitleText: Assumption of Permeability in Portions Before and Abaft the Machinery Space

Section.Text: In ships to which this Division applies, the assumed average permeability throughout the portions of the ship before and abaft the machinery space shall be determined

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by the following formula:

FormulaDefinition.Text: the volume of the spaces that are situated below the margin line before or abaft the machinery space, as the case may be, and above the tops of floors, inner bottom, or peak tanks, and which are appropriated for use as coal or oil fuel bunkers, store rooms, baggage rooms, mail rooms, chain lockers or fresh water tanks and of spaces appropriated for cargo if the Board is satisfied the greater part of the volume of the space is intended to be occupied by cargo; and
v =the volume of the portion of the ship below the margin line before or abaft the machinery space, as the case may be; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the Board so determines in the case of any ship, after receipt of a plan of the ship showing the watertight subdivision thereof, by detailed calculation, for the purpose of which the permeability of spaces shall be assumed to be as follows:

Provision.Text: passenger spaces 95
crew spaces 95
spaces appropriated to machinery 80
spaces appropriated to bunker coal, stores or baggage rooms 60
spaces appropriated to cargo, tanks forming part of the structure of the ship and double bottoms 95,
or such lesser figure as the Board may permit in the case of any ship.

Subsection.Text: Subject to this section, the factor of subdivision of ships to which this Division applies shall be the factor determined in the manner provided in section 4 of this Schedule, or 0.5 whichever is the lesser, provided that if the Board is satisfied in the case of any ship, the length of which is less than 91.5 m, that it is impracticable to apply that factor to any compartment it may allow a higher factor to be applied to that compartment.

If in the case of any ship to which this Division applies the Board is satisfied that the quantity of cargo to be carried in the ship will be such as to render impracticable the application abaft the collision bulkhead of a factor of subdivision not exceeding 0.5, the factor of subdivision of the ship shall be determined as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of ships the length of which is 131 m and upwards, by the formula:

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of ships the length of which is less than 131 m but not less than 55 m, and having a criterion numeral not less than S1, by the formula:

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: for the purposes of the above formulae:

FormulaDefinition.Text: = the criterion numeral determined in accordance with section 5 of this Schedule where P1 has the following values:

FormulaParagraph.Label: (i)
FormulaParagraph.Text: 0.56LN or 3.55N whichever is the greater for berthed passengers,

FormulaParagraph.Label: (iii)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of ships the length of which is less than 131 m but not less than 55 m and having a criterion numeral less than S1, and of all ships the length of which is less than 55 m, the factor of subdivision shall be unity.

Section.Text: In accordance with section 2 of this Schedule, the method described in this Division should generally be adopted to develop flooding curves to indicate the floodable length at any point in the ship; for the purpose of this method, the floodable length is expressed as a percentage of the length of the ship.
In this Division,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: except where otherwise stated,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: all linear measurements shall be in metres,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all area measurements shall be in square metres, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all volumes shall be in cubic metres and calculated to moulded lines;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the load waterplane is that used in determining the subdivision of the ship, and is drawn parallel to the keel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the margin line for a ship of standard form consists of two ordinary parabolas, each with apex at amidships and axis vertical, passing, at amidships and at the ends, through points 76 mm below the surface of the bulkhead deck at side;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the corrected margin line, if the actual margin line either forward or aft is not of ordinary parabolic form* or if its lowest point is not at amidships, a margin line of ordinary parabolic form shall be drawn with its apex amidships level with the lowest point of the actual margin line, and intersecting the latter either at a point one quarter of the ship’s length from amidships or at the perpendicular according as the actual sheer at the perpendicular is respectively greater or less than four times the actual sheer at the one-quarter length position, (see Fig. A in this Schedule);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the perpendiculars are taken at the extreme ends of the subdivision load water line;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: amidships is the middle of the length between the perpendiculars;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the mean waterplane is midway between the load water plane and that drawn parallel thereto touching the lowest point of the margin line;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the length of the ship (L) is the length of a ship measured between the perpendiculars taken at the extremities of the deepest subdivision load water line, (section 2); no adjustment to this length will, as a general rule, be necessary unless the sectional area at the after perpendicular exceeds one tenth of the midship sectional area, in which case full particulars shall be submitted in order that an equitable length may be determined;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the breadth of the ship (B) is the greatest moulded breadth at or below the ship’s deepest subdivision load water line, (section 2);

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the draught (d) is the vertical distance from the moulded base line amidships to a subdivision load water line, (section 2);

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the freeboard (f) is the vertical distance amidships from the subdivision load water line to the margin line (corrected as necessary);

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the block coefficient of fineness of displacement to the subdivision load water line shall be determined as follows: volume of displacement to moulded lines divided by (L.B.d.);

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the freeboard ratio (fd) is the ratio between the freeboard (f) and the draught (d);

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the sheer ratio forward or aft is the ratio of the sheer of the margin line (corrected as necessary) at the forward or after perpendicular respectively, measured from the horizontal line through the lowest point of the margin line (corrected as necessary), to the draught;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the mean waterplane area coefficient (a) is the actual area of mean waterplane divided by L × B;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: the mean waterplane moment of inertia coefficient (n) is the actual moment of inertia of mean waterplane about a transverse axis through its centre of flotation divided by L3 × B;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: the sectional area coefficient (ß) for any transverse section is the actual area of that section up to the margin line divided by B × d;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the Standard Diagrams of Floodable Lengths, etc. (or Plates) are as set out in section 12 of this Schedule and the Plates referred to are the numbered Diagrams in that section.

Footnote.Text: A margin or ordinary parabolic form is one in which the sheer forward and aft measured at points 1/8, 1/4 and 3/8 of the length of the ship from the perpendicular is 9/16, 1/4 and 1/16 respectively of the sheer at the perpendicular.

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: In determining the floodable length, a uniform average permeability shall be used throughout the whole length of each of the following portions of the ship below the margin line :

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the machinery space,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)

Heading.TitleText: Calculations of Stability in Damaged Condition

Section.Text: The sufficiency of intact stability of every ship to which Part I of these Regulations applies shall be determined by calculation, which has regard to the design and construction of the ship and the damaged compartments and is in accordance with the following assumptions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ship shall be assumed to be in the worst condition as regards stability that is likely to be experienced having regard to the intended service of the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the volume permeabilities and surface permeabilities shall be assumed to be as follows:

row.entry: Appropriated to cargo, coal or stores
Appropriated to accommodation for passengers and crew
0 or 95, whichever results in the more onerous requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum extent of damage shall be assumed to be as follows:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: longitudinal extent: 3.05 m plus 3 per cent of the length of the ship, or 10.67 m, or 10 per cent of the length of the ship, whichever is the least,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: transverse extent: 20 per cent of the breadth of the ship (measured inboard from the ship’s side at right angles to the centre line at the level of the deepest subdivision load water line),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: vertical extent: from the top of the double bottom up to the margin line,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: if any damage of lesser extent than that indicated in subparagraphs (i), (ii) and (iii) would result in a more severe condition regarding heel or loss of metacentric height, such damage shall be assumed for the purposes of the calculation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the ship is fitted with decks, inner skins or longitudinal bulkheads of sufficient tightness to restrict the flow of water, regard shall be had to such restrictions in the calculation.

Heading.TitleText: Sufficiency of Stability in Damaged Condition

Section.Text: The intact stability of the ship shall be deemed to be sufficient if the calculation mentioned in section 1 shows that, after the assumed damage and after equalization measures have been taken, the final condition of the ship is as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of unsymmetrical flooding, the metacentric height is positive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of unsymmetrical flooding, the heel does not exceed seven degrees, except that in special cases the Board may allow additional heel, but in no case shall the final heel exceed 15 degrees; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of unsymmetrical flooding, the margin line is not submerged.

Section.Text: Automatic equalization measures are preferable and complete details in this regard shall be submitted with the calculations; all pipes concerned shall be of suitable area to permit rapid counter flooding; where air and filling or overflow pipes are led to a common main, care shall be taken that in the event of damage there is no leakage to intact compartments through these or any other pipes.
